Description: Mould-made oil-lamp in the form of a ram. Mould-made in a two piece mould and hollow. A pierced look on the back operated as a suspension loop. Covered in a glossy red slip. Pale yellow calcaric (marl) fabric. Traces of burning on the nozzle.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Unclear pencil markings appear to state 'sanctuary' and 'April 27 1802'. Dated by the Fitwilliam Museum to the 2nd or 4th century AD. Similar fabric, slip and style mould-made lamp, but in the form of a lion, from Egypt, dated to the 5th or 6th century AD (Louvre, Paris, AO 25780).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KF.01) (Phase 3)
